EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
The Air Liquide Las Vegas LH2 facility maintains a written emergency action plan (EAP). The Las Vegas LH2 EAP is reviewed and trained on annually. The Las Vegas LH2 employees are trained to first responder awareness level to be ready in the event of accidental releases of a regulated substance. The EAP provides details for the safe evacuation of facility personnel, contractors and visitors. The EAP plan contains outside agency contact information and the notification process and information on emergency health care in the event of a loss of containment of the Las Vegas LH2 flammable covered process.

Safe & Hot Work Permit System
Air Liquide has a safe & hot work permit system in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  This system is comprised of a group of corporate procedures and standards under the life safety program. Procedures in place include: energy control, safe work, hot work, confined space entry and process line break. Facility personnel are trained on these safe work practices to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Contractors
Air Liquide uses outside contractors to support maintenance activities. Contractors are made aware of the potential dangers involved with a system covered by PSM/RMP. Procedures are in place to make sure that contractors: (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, and (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency prior to their beginning work. Periodically contractors are evaluated to ensure that both their safety performance and training required for work on the hydrogen purification process.

CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
Air Liquide's accidental release prevention program activities helps prevent potential accident
scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors. The following are examples of the types of safety features in place:
Automated process control shutdowns
Automatic and manual valves that provide for isolation of the process
Manual Emergency process shutdowns located in the control room and process area
Pressure Safety Relief Valves and Flare system
Deluge system, fire water monitor, and hydrant system
Special personal protective equipment (e.g., FRC protective clothing,)
Personal/portable ambient air monitors

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)
Air Liquide ensures the safety of new/modified facilities or processes before placing those facilities or processes into service through the use of pre-startup safety reviews (PSSRs). PSSRs are intended to ensure safety through confirmation that: (1) construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; (2) safety, operating, maintenance and emergency
procedures are in place and adequate; (3) PHAs have been performed and recommendations
resolved before startup of new plants or processes; (4) MOC requirements have been satisfied for modified facilities; and (5) training has been completed for affected employees.

Compliance Audits
To help ensure the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Air Liquide conducts an
audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accidental release
prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years. Resolutions to the recommendations are documented, tracked and closed.
Incident Investigation Air Liquide defines management systems and establishes the requirements for communicating, investigating and reporting of incidents at all facilities through the use of an Incident Investigation and reporting procedure. Air Liquide documents incident and subsequent investigation, follow up actions, and closure. Results of findings and corrective actions are shared with employees who could be affected by the findings.

Employee Participation
At the North Vegas LH2 facility, employees are expected to participate in accidental release prevention program (PSM/RMP). Employees are trained on and are provided access to the hydrogen process safety information. The specific ways an employee can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in the Employee Participation plan. Forms of participation include being part of a PHA, a PSSR, and

n of classroom, computer-based (CBT) and hands-on training that addresses such topic as: general orientation, site rules and practices, process safety information, normal and emergency operating procedures, health and safety consideration, use of safety procedures and equipment, incident investigation and emergency response. In addition, all operators are required to attend refresher training at least every three years. Training is documented and tracked in the electronic learning management system.

Mechanical Integrity
Air Liquide has established mechanical integrity (MI) practices and procedures, based on
preventative philosophy, to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, and relief valves and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests; (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.
The MI program assists with the verification and suitability of new and existing process equipment and, as well as quality control of spare parts and modifications to existing process equipment.

Management of Change
Air Liquide's management of change (MOC) procedure has established the requirements for
ensuring that proposed process or equipment changes or changes indirectly affecting processes are evaluated, approved, and documented prior to implementation through the use of a management of change process. The MOC procedure outlines the requirements for documenting, evaluating the impact, and approving planned changes. All MOC's are submitted, reviewed by subject matter specialist (such as Engineering, Risk Management, Operations, Health and Safety), approved, tracked, and closed. Process Safety Information (PSI)
Air Liquide keeps a variety of technical documents onsite electronically that are used to help
maintain safe operation of its processes. These documents address chemical properties and
associated hazards, equipment design/configuration information, specific chemical inventories and operation limits for key process parameters - all key information for operating the process safely.

Process Hazard Analysis
Air Liquide has a risk management program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. The covered process underwent an initial process hazard analysis (PHA) and continues to undergo periodic PHA's and PHA re-validations at least every five years. The PHA team consists of members with the appropriate experience to define the hazards.  The PHA team will review findings and develop a resolution action plan for each item, which will be documented, tracked and ultimately closed in the Air Liquide action item tracking system.

Operating Procedures
Air Liquide maintains written procedures that address various modes of hydrogen purification
process operations, such as (1) unit initial startup; (2) unit normal and temporary operations; (3) unit shutdown; (4) emergency shutdown; (5) startup following an emergency shutdown; and (6) process deviation, consequence and action. These procedures are used by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.

OVERVIEW
Air Liquide Hydrogen Energy U.S. LLC (Air Liquide) North Las Vegas Liquid Hydrogen production unit (North Vegas LH2) process is located in North Las Vegas, NV.   The Air Liquide commitment to safety and environmental protection for the Air Liquide North Las Vegas Liquid Hydrogen Facility extends beyond the plant. As part of the community, Air Liquide has a responsibility to our customer, near neighbors and the community at large to help provide a safe working and living environment. Through safety, concern for the environment, and community involvement, we can develop a true partnership with our customer and community.

Regulated Chemical and Covered Process
The Las Vegas LH2 facility consists of a hydrogen steam methane reformer (SMR) and hydrogen liquefier including a 475,510-gallon liquid hydrogen storage sphere and a dispenser system for trailer loading and unloading.  The volume of liquid hydrogen stored onsite makes this site a covered process as defined under the Federal and state accidental release prevention regulations, as a flammable mixture process having an inventory in excess of 10,000 pounds.

The Hydrogen Facility steam methane reforming process is designed to provide an efficient
production of high purity hydrogen using a natural gas feedstock. The hydrogen reforming and purification is performed at elevated pressure. High pressure purified hydrogen is then liquified. The North Las Vegas LH2 Facility is designed for continuous safe operation.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS
Air Liquide North Vegas LH2 is covered by EPA's accidental release prevention program regulations and is subject to OSHA's process safety management (PSM) standard. The North Vegas LH2 process is closely monitored and controlled to prevent accidental releases to the environment.
